awd_titl_txt: Tenocyte Mechanobiology in a Fiber Composite Mimetic
awd_abstract_narration:
Tendons are an important tissue for musculoskeletal function -- they connect muscles to bones.  They are also a very slow healing tissue, due in part to the limited blood supply and small concentration of cells within the highly fibrous structure.  If tendon cells, tenocytes, are going to be stimulated to enhance tendon growth and regeneration, it is vitally important that the understanding of how these cells respond to their mechanical environment is substantially increased.  This project will use a combination of computer modeling and experimental studies to investigate how tenocytes respond to complex loading normally seen in a tendon.  The work will focus on the micro-level -- in order to understand how variations in the mechanical environment just around the cell relate to the cellular response.  In addition to advancing knowledge that will support future work in tissue engineering of tendons and other fibrous connective tissue, this project includes several educational and outreach activities.  First, the research team will integrate students from high school through graduate school in order to help them understand the importance of research in this area and of integrating experimental and computational techniques.  Next, there will be an opportunity for graduate students to travel to an international collaborator's laboratory to enhance their scientific preparation.  Finally, hands-on workshops will be developed to provide participants with a broader understanding of connective tissue biomechanics.

The overall objectives for this project are to: (1) determine the micromechanics and the type and magnitude of the local cellular strains as a function of fiber composite properties under physiologically relevant tensile strains; (2) determine tenocyte anabolic and catabolic metabolism as a function of the type and magnitude of the local cellular strains and the typed of integrin-ligand interaction; and (3) elucidate intracellular signaling pathways based on MAP kinase signaling that are involved in integratin-mediated mechanotransduction within tenocytes.  This will be done through the development of a computational model of tenocytes within a fiber-reinforced structure and the validation of this model with experimental studies using a novel hydrogel-fiber composite mimetic that captures aspects of the tendon's fiber composite mechanics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The loading environment in tendon is sustained by functioning as a short fiber composite. Extension at the tissue level occurs predominantly by fiber extension and sliding between adjacent collagen units. To study the mechanobiology of tendon, this research has developed a novel fiber composite material designed to mimetic the structure and function of tendon. The synthetic mimetic is comprised of short discontinuous fiber-like polymeric structures that are embedded in a bulk matrix made of a hydrogel. When the fiber composite mimetic is subjected to a tensile strain, the fibers within the mimetic stretch (i.e., extend) and slide past one another, recapitulating key characteristics of the mechanical response of tendon. The overarching goal is for the mimetic to be used as a model system to study how structure influences mechanical response in tendons. This model can provide new insights into how altered structures in damaged or diseased tendons can impact their mechanical response, ultimately affecting the cells that reside within the tissue and contributing to tendon pathophysiology.

Utilizing a combined experimental and computational approach, this research investigated the interaction between the fibers and the bulk matrix in the synthetic fiber composite mimetic. Through manipulations in the structure, this research was able to alter the extent to which the fibers and matrix integrate and identified that this integration plays a significant role in determining the mechanical response of the fiber composite. When integration is limited, fibers are unable to extend and primarily slide past one another, mimicking that of pathological tendons. On the contrary, when integration is strong, fibers primarily undergo extension with limited sliding. This research also demonstrated that the type of chemical bond that forms at the interface between the fiber and the bulk matrix dramatically impacts the mechanical response. Specifically, chemical bonds can be stable or dynamic. Dynamic bonds can form, break, and reform under stress and are largely responsible for the viscoelastic properties observed in many tissues. Using computational modeling, this research has shown that when dynamic bonds dominate in the fiber composite, it can lead to permanent (plastic) deformation, a characteristic of damaged tendon. Collectively, this research has identified that the nature by which fibers and the surrounding matrix interact through the extent of the integration as well as the types of bonds at the interface. These features significantly impact how a fiber composite functions under mechanical strain. This synthetic mimetic system can readily be extended to incorporate cells along the fibers to understand how differences in the mechanical response impact cellular responses. This research has been incorporated into an advanced graduate course for Biological Engineering graduate students on Cell and Tissue Systems. This research has supported three graduate students though their PhD and provided summer research experiences for undergraduate students from universities outside of Colorado.

 


Last Modified: 09/08/2024
Modified by: Stephanie J Bryant
